text: on August 11th 2016 researchers working
with paralyzed people announced a
surprising outcome the patients were
getting better the team led by Duke
University neuroscientist Miguel
Nicolelis discovered that his patients
regained partial sensation and muscle
control in their lower limbs by training
with brain controlled robotics this is
an example of one of our patients that
was trained to use a non-invasive
technique EEG - imagine walking in this
signals basically translate translated
into digital commands that go to a
robotic exoskeleton that he's wearing
and not only he can walk with his device
but we have sensors all over the
exoskeleton that they had one pressure
sensors when he touches the ground there
is a pressure wave that is generated and
delivered to a vibrating element on his
arm we found a way to give them the
feeling that is not the axle that is
carrying them but is them walking with
the X and it was very realistic we have
been working with all these eight
patients for 24 months now yeah and the
most beautiful part is now we know
because we have done neurological
examination these guys and have been
chronic spinal cord lesions yeah they
have been in the wheelchair for a decade
two years later seven of these patients
have recovered sensitivity below the
level of the injury in motor control
voluntary motor control of some muscles
below the level deletion so I think
plasticity was triggered by this
exercise of imagining you're walking and
getting this feedback that is very
realistic so this conjunction of the
output to control device and the
feedback that feels like my body is
moving may have trigger
axons they were left nerves they've
survived the original lesion - to start
working again our expectation is that we
are going to reduce the time that it
takes for a paraplegic patient to regain
and the concept of having legs and being
able to control them mentally so they
can move to the exoskeleton faster I
think that's brilliant and that's
wonderful not only because it's great
science but because it also reflects one
of the slogans of the disability
community is there's nothing about us
without us I think that's a great you
know merge of what we need is in
individuals as human beings or
differences our personalities our
disabilities plus how to bring the
science together that's a great Center
what they like they tell us is that most
of physical rehabilitation the classical
one is passive what are their in a
physical therapist is trying to move
your leg and you're just there receiving
that in this kind of thing you are a
protagonist
